children.subject:
Strictly speaking, (at least when I took the class) students were allowed to use any programming language that they wanted.

It's recommended to use C++ because most other people do, so it helps with debugging. You can learn to write ugly C++ code (basically writing C with classes) quickly enough that it won't be an issue if you know C. The important part of the class is understanding the algorithms and such; I think the projects are fairly straightforward to implement once you know what to do.
Also, I believe the coding projects are in c++. If we don't know c++, are we gonna be fine?

history.content: You should take 184 if the material seems interesting to you. It isn't a class I'd recommend if you have no interest in graphics and I wouldn't consider it a must-take by any stretch. Basically if you think computer graphics are cool and you are interested in learning how to implement graphics rendering like what you see in video games and movies and animation, go for it.

children.subject:
It is definitely less about the animation/effects/visually cool stuff that comes to mind when you think Pixar or video games, and more about the fundamental technical concepts behind it. Projects this semester were rasterizing pixels to a screen, constructing geometric meshes, building a pathtracer, building camera lens. You could think of highly advanced versions of these projects to be something like Maya. You're not working in Maya. You're building Maya.

In the games/animation/movies pipeline, it's basically waaaaay in the beginning (or present in the background of every step, depending on how you look at it). Check out the video about fur in Zootopia and that would be what you learn about rendering at a very very high level. There's a tiny bit about animation concepts in the end, but if you want to learn animation I'd recommend UCBUGG instead of 184. If you are interested in doing software development for graphics tools, however, 184 is great. It's definitely my favorite class yet.

Thanks for the answer.

When people say "things you see in video games and animation/movies", sure, what Pixar does and the CGI stuff in movies are cool and I definitely want to learn those, but, the problem is, is that actually what this class is about / what this class teaches? I've looked at some of the images and projects from 184 and it doesn't quite seem like it.

I guess I don't know exactly what "184/computer graphics" is and where it fits in in games/animation/movies.

history.subject: How useful is CS 184 and who should take it?
